data.title: Courteney Cox Feels Matthew Perry Is Still There for Her: “He Visits Me a Lot”
data.meta_description: In an interview with ‘CBS Sunday Morning,’ the ‘Friends’ star spoke about her ongoing spiritual connection with her late costar. “I sense Matthew’s around, for sure,” she said.
data.text:
Even after death, Matthew Perry is still there for Courteney Cox. In an interview with CBS Sunday Morning, the Friends star opened up about her ongoing connection with the late Perry, who died last year at the age of 54.

“I think he’s probably one of the funniest human beings in the world. You know, he’s just so funny,” said Cox. “He is genuinely a huge heart, obviously struggled. I’m so thankful I got to work so closely with him for so many years. He visits me a lot, if we believe in that.”

Cox and Perry played friends turned lovers Monica and Chandler on Friends for a decade, from 1994 to 2004. This month marks the 20th anniversary of the Friends series finale, “The Last One,” which Cox commemorated on her Instagram page. “It’s been 20 years since the series finale of Friends,” she wrote. “I don’t know how we were able to act through all the tears. Forever grateful.”

In the interview promoting Cox’s new homeware line, Homecourt, CBS Sunday Morning reporter Jonathan Vigliotti pointed out that Cox is a spiritual person, prompting Cox to talk about her ongoing connection with her deceased parents, Richard Lewis Cox and Courteney Copeland, and Perry. “I talk to my mom, my dad, Matthew. I feel like there are a lot of people that, I think, guide us,” she said. “I do sense—I sense Matthew’s around, for sure.”

On October 28, 2023, Perry, who struggled for years with drug and alcohol use, was pronounced dead after he was found unresponsive in a hot tub at his home in the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles. An autopsy found that Perry’s death was accidental and that he died of “acute effects of ketamine.” Other contributors to Perry’s death included drowning, coronary artery disease, and the effects of a drug, buprenorphine, used to treat opioid use disorder.

After Perry’s passing, Cox paid tribute to Perry with Friends costars Jennifer Aniston, David Schwimmer, Lisa Kudrow, and Matt LeBlanc. “We are all so utterly devastated by the loss of Matthew,” they said in a joint statement to People. “We were more than just castmates. We are a family.” Cox honored Perry individually on Instagram by posting an outtake from the iconic scene in which it’s first revealed that Monica and Chandler slept together.

“Chandler and Monica were supposed to have a one night fling in London. But because of the audience’s reaction, it became the beginning of their love story,” she wrote. “In this scene, before we started rolling, he whispered a funny line for me to say. He often did things like that. He was funny and he was kind.”
